newsitem.title: USA: Wife of Delaware governor says charges untrue.
newsitem.headline: Wife of Delaware governor says charges untrue.

text.p: A Republican leader on Monday accused Delaware's governor of spousal abuse but the charges were denied late in the day by the governor's wife.

In a meeting with reporters in the governor's office, Martha Carper, wife of Gov. Thomas Carper, a Democrat who is seeking re-election for a second term, said, "I am not an abused wife and my children have not been abused by their father ... and I have never been treated in an emergency room in my life ... I love my husband and he loves me."

She was responding to charges made by chairwoman Ann Stone of Washington, D.C.-based Republicans for Choice at a news conference earlier in the day that allegations of divorce and spousal abuse against Carper had "been covered up for political reasons."
Stone alleged that if unspecified court documents were unsealed they would substantiate her story, but Mrs. Carper said no such documents exist.
Martha Carper married Thomas Carper in 1985 when he was a second-term congressman and they have two sons, aged 8 and 6.

Carper stayed away from his wife's news conference at her request, but in a statement he said, "This kind of political smear is not only hurtful to me and my family, but also to Delawareans' confidence in the political process."

At the Carpers' request, the chief judge of the Delaware Family Court, Vincent Poppiti, issued a verifying order that there were "no filings at any time in the Family Court regarding (Martha and Thomas Carper's) marriage." The court's proceedings are confidential.

But Stone made public on Monday for the first time a July 29, 1981, deposition in which Carper admitted slapping his first wife Diane. In 1982 the incident was a front page story in the New York Post.

"It was a stupid thing to do and I realised it then, and regret it now. It caused some discoloration of her left eye and some puffiness," Carper testified in the deposition, adding, "It wasn't the kind of thing that was enduring or really all that significant."

Carper's Republican opponent for governor, state treasurer Janet Rzewnicki, denied charges by Martha Carper and Democratic Party state chairman Gary Hindes that her campaign "was responsible for" Stone's trip to Delaware.
